newsitem.title: CHINA: HK stocks rebound in morning, led by properties.
newsitem.headline: HK stocks rebound in morning, led by properties.

text.p: Hong Kong stocks rebounded in early Monday trading after opening easier following Wall Street's lower close on Friday on a spate of strong U.S. economic data, brokers said.
The blue chip Hang Seng Index rose 51 points, or 0.31 percent, to 16,430 after erasing a 82 point loss in the opening minutes.

"The rebound is led by properties as investors believe that the local property market has bottomed out and end-users have started to enter the market to buy flats," said Peter Lai, associate director at OCBC Securities.
Some property developers have cut prices on new flat sales and this made people believe that the government would not take drastic measures to curb prices, Lai said.
Cheung Kong added HK$0.50 to HK$87.75 and Sun Hung Kai Properties rose HK$0.50 to HK$101.50.
"Trading volume is quite good so far but it's too early to say whether the Hang Seng could hit new high today," Lai added.
The Hang Seng posted an intra-day record of 16,449.53 last Friday.
Hongkong Telecom added HK$0.15 to HK$19.95 on derivatives-linked trading, brokers said.
HSBC Holdings was down HK$1.00 at HK$267.00 and Hang Seng Bank was unchanged at HK$112.50 ahead of their interim result announcements due later in the day.
"The market generally expect good earnings for the banks so there is no major selling seen in the counters today," said Antony Mak, sales director at Vickers Ballas.
Dickson rose HK$0.65 to HK$27.50 on optimism that it would win in a bid for U.S. clothing retailer Barney's Inc, brokers said.
Barney's is to announce the successful bidder later today and Dickson will hold a new conference this afternoon.
Chevalier OA International Ltd surged HK$0.73, or 72 percent, to a year high of HK$1.74 before steadying at HK$1.52, up HK$0.51.
Buying was fuelled by news that the China State Council backed China Everbright Technology Ltd's plan to take a 10 percent stake in Chevalier OA, Mak said.
Red-chips and H-shares were slightly up on selective buying.
Shanghai Haixing rose HK$0.35 to HK$5.70 and Yizheng added HK$0.225 to HK$2.85. The two counters were driven by news that their mainland parents were planning corporate restructurings.
